main

Class HuffmanCoding<K,V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • main.HuffmanCoding<K,V>
  • Type Parameters:
    K - - Key used to find the value
    V - - Value associated with the key
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    InterfaceHuffmanCoding<K,V>

    public class HuffmanCoding<K,V>
extends java.lang.Object
implements InterfaceHuffmanCoding<K,V>
    Main classes where the Interface methods are implemented to their specifications and their respective JavaDoc. This code creates a Huffman code based on the Frequency Distribution of their respective character. It has a preMain class that calls the File Path and File name. Each method is explained more in details in ea
    Author:
    Maria Alejandra Munoz Valenzuela

      • huffman_tree

        public BTNode.ComparableKey<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.String> huffman_tree(HashTableSC<java.lang.String,java.lang.Integer> fd)
        Description copied from interface: InterfaceHuffmanCoding
        This methods takes the Frequency Distribution and turns into the Huffman Root Node that we need to save the newly encoded characters. First with the helper method (sorting) passes the HashTable into a SortedArrayList. Once that is done, it begans to construct the Root. It checks the frequencies and if they are the same, then it needs to see which is the smaller one which is done with the compareTo with the values of the node. If the first node is smaller than the second, then it goes into the helper method that adds the leftChild first. Once it has added the leftChild, it adds the rightChild, and that's why I use 0 instead of anything else because I need to add the ones at the top. When it's the first node is bigger than the second node, then the rightChild is added first and then the leftChild. This is the way it's done because I need the "smaller" value on the left side and the bigger one on the right side. After only one node is left (which will have all the children), it simple returns this ComparableKey which is the root. Has two helper methods: 1) huffman_tree_left: which is just repeated code, this how I avoid repeated when it adds the leftChild first and then the rightChildren. 2) sorting: this is where the HashTable is turned into a SortedArrayList so that the lowest frequencies are on the top.
        Specified by:
        huffman_tree in interface InterfaceHuffmanCoding<K,V>
        Parameters:
        fd - - HashTableSC that has how many times a letter has been repeated inside the file given.
        Returns:
        Root of the newly created Huffman Tree

      • huffman_tree_left

        private void huffman_tree_left(BTNode.ComparableKey<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.String> N,
                               SortedArrayList<BTNode.ComparableKey<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.String>> nodes)

      • huffman_code

        public HashTableSC<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> huffman_code(BTNode.ComparableKey<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.String> root)
        Description copied from interface: InterfaceHuffmanCoding
        This method has two helper method which complete the idea of what needs to happen inside it. This are: 1) huffman_code_ aux: which is a recursive method that traverses through the left and right children to get the code. Adding 1 when it's a right child, adding 0 when it's a left child. 2) depth: which is used to create the HashTable with the size of the initial root.
        Specified by:
        huffman_code in interface InterfaceHuffmanCoding<K,V>
        Parameters:
        root - - ComparableKey that holds the root of the created Huffman Tree
        Returns:
        HashTableSC with the respective codes that encode each letter inside of the original input

                              java.lang.String s,
                              HashTableSC<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> result)
        Used in huffman_code.
        Parameters:
        root - - ComparableKey that holds the root of the huffman tree.
        s - - String with the new meaning to the character.
        result - - HashTableSC that holds the newly created code.

      • depth

      • encode

        public java.lang.String encode(HashTableSC<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> huffmancode,
                               java.lang.String input)
        Description copied from interface: InterfaceHuffmanCoding
        Takes the input string and turns into the newly encoded String. It is basically just taking each character from the input and using it as a key to find the value that was found inside of the huffmancode parameter. It's fairly simple and once found it is simply added to the result string that is returned.
        Specified by:
        encode in interface InterfaceHuffmanCoding<K,V>
        Parameters:
        huffmancode - - HashTableSC that holds the letters from the original string with their new code to be written.
        input - - String that holds the initial string inside the file
        Returns:
        String that holds the newly encoded string

      • sorting

        public void sorting(HashTableSC<java.lang.String,java.lang.Integer> fd,
                    SortedArrayList<BTNode.ComparableKey<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.String>> nodes)
        Helper method used to add the fd into the SortedArrayList so that the smallest is on the top. Used in: huffman_tree and process_results.
        Parameters:
        fd - - HashTableSC that has how many times a letter has been repeated inside the file given.
        nodes - - ComparableKey that holds the root of the huffman tree.

      • process_results

        public void process_results(HashTableSC<java.lang.String,java.lang.Integer> fd,
                            HashTableSC<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> huffmancode,
                            java.lang.String input,
                            java.lang.String output)
                     throws java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException
        Description copied from interface: InterfaceHuffmanCoding
        This method prints put the results. It takes the frequency distribution and sorts it so that it can be printed from the highest frequency to the lowest frequency. In that same line, it looks for the code for that specific character. Once that is done, it is simple counting the bites from each string and printing them out to the console. I saved this values so that it's easier to read for the percentage. And once I have the percentage which is just a simple math equation of error, we have all the values that were asked for and in the way that it's wanted.
        Specified by:
        process_results in interface InterfaceHuffmanCoding<K,V>
        Parameters:
        fd - - HashTableSC that has how many times a letter has been repeated inside the file given.
        huffmancode - - HashTableSC that holds the letters from the original string with their new code to be written.
        input - - String that holds the initial string from the file given.
        output - - String that holds the newly encoded string.
        Throws:
        java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException
